subject: statistics
statementHtml: Compare the variances of two datasets to determine if they have the same underlying distribution. Given n1 observations with sample variance s1^2, and n2 observations with sample variance s2^2, test the null hypothesis that both variances are equal (H0: σ1^2 = σ2^2) against the alternative hypothesis that at least one variance is larger (H1: σ1^2 ≠ σ2^2).
hints: Start by calculating the sample means and standard deviations of both datasets.
Consider using the F-statistic to compare the variances.
Remember to adjust for degrees of freedom when calculating the p-value.
solutionHtml:
First, calculate the sample means and standard deviations:

\[ ar{x}_1 = rac{1}{n_1} \sum_{i=1}^{n_1} x_i,\quad ar{x}_2 = rac{1}{n_2} \sum_{j=1}^{n_2} y_j, \] \[ s_1^2 = rac{1}{n_1-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n_1} (x_i - ar{x}_1)^2,\quad s_2^2 = rac{1}{n_2-1} \sum_{j=1}^{n_2} (y_j - ar{x}_2)^2. \]

Next, calculate the F-statistic:

\[ F = rac{s_1^2 / n_1}{s_2^2 / n_2}. \]

Finally, use this value to determine if the null hypothesis can be rejected.

",
answerShort: Reject or fail to reject H0" },

subject: statistics
title: F-Tests: Comparing Variances

problem.statementHtml: Consider two independent samples from normal distributions with unknown variances. Test whether the variances are equal.
hints: The F-distribution is involved in this problem.
Think about how to set up a ratio of variance estimates.
Use the fact that the F-statistic follows an F-distribution under the null hypothesis.
problem.solutionHtml: To perform the F-test, calculate the sample variances and the pooled variance. Then, compute the F-statistic as the ratio of the larger sample variance to the smaller one. Finally, compare this value to the critical region from an F-distribution table or calculator.

commonMistakes: Forgetting to calculate the pooled variance
Using the wrong ratio for the F-statistic

subject: statistics
title: F-Tests: Comparing Variances
statementHtml: Given two datasets with sample sizes $n_1$ and $n_2$, we want to test whether their variances are equal or not.
hints: Think about how you would compare the means of these datasets.
Recall that F-distributions are used for comparing variances.
solutionHtml:
To perform an F-test, first calculate the sample variance $s_1^2$ and $s_2^2$. Then, calculate the mean squared error (MSE) of each dataset.

Next, compute the F-statistic:

\[F = \frac{s_1^2}{s_2^2}\]
